awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Electrochemical Acoustic Tools for the Analysis of Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project lies in the ability of this technology to impact how every battery is made, tested, managed, and re-used in the near future. Batteries are ubiquitous, and their use is likely to increase in the future. As such, there is a growing need for low-cost, accurate methods for monitoring the state of charge (SOC) and the state of health (SOH) in real time to optimize performance and maximize lifetime. The technology that will be developed in this project will use ultrasound to noninvasively probe batteries and provide physical insights into SOC and SOH, and will work on any closed battery regardless of chemistry and form factor. Initial finding of this hypothesis have already been demonstrated and published. This is an unexplored area and presents a large commercial opportunity in each sector of the battery industry, including diagnostics, quality assurance, active cycling control, and the emerging second-life markets. Several advantages include sensitivity to subtle physical changes within cells, the ability to probe lab and commercial scale cells, and sub-millisecond readings. From battery R&D, to manufacturing, to management systems, ultrasound for batteries will help enable the efficient generation, storage, and use of energy worldwide.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will support the development of this technology leading to the first commercial ultrasonic battery analysis unit. The feasibility of 1) miniaturized pulser-receivers with pulsing and switching speeds that are orders of magnitude faster than commercial units, and 2) miniaturized transducers that can transmit and receive high quality signals will be demonstrated. This would enable the detection of high-rate phenomena and the use of multiplexed systems. 3) The use of fast data analysis algorithms for real-time SOC prediction using acoustics as the main input will also be addressed. These objectives are necessary for demonstrating the applicability of ultrasonic analysis to the battery R&D, manufacturing, and second life markets. The success of Phase I of this project will lead to the development of micron-scale sensors for incorporation in battery management systems. In Phase II, algorithms for SOH prediction and cycling control based on acoustic data will be developed, as well as investigation of the design and fabrication of microelectronic transducers will be performed.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This NSF Small Business Innovation Research Phase I award supported the development and commercialization of a new approach to analyzing batteries that uses sound waves. During the project period, Feasible Inc. validated that there is a strong need in the industry for at-scale diagnostics that give good information about internal structure of cells, most urgently in Quality Control (QC) as well as in battery management and monitoring systems. 

With the support of NSF, Feasible Inc. evaluated the various components of our hardware and software designs in order to determine if, from a technical feasibility standpoint, it would even be possible to build a system with a high-enough degree of acoustic signal repeatability that subtle differences between battery samples could reliably be measured.

This involved screening a number of elastomer couplants to ensure good contact between the battery sample and acoustic transducers, as well as modifying our hardware system to use a pneumatic approach to actuating and applying consistent pressure on the transducers. That gave us the ability to cleanly assess the influence of pressure and driving voltage level on the acoustic signal quality, as well the influence of temperature. Finally, we ran signal repeatability and reliability tests to quantify the variability in our acoustic measurement. This gives us a baseline against which to compare sample data and future hardware improvements against. 

With standardized designs for our hardware and software, we can now build a robust, automated benchtop prototype. This can be used to perform higher throughput measurements of batches of batteries in order to assess their quality distributions as well as the ways that information can be used to improve the performance of groupings of cells. Our goal is to develop and commercialize acoustic quality analysis systems that can seamlessly fit into existing battery quality control workflows on assembly lines at both battery manufacturers and battery purchasers.

This class of products has broad societal impacts, as batteries are ubiquitous and their use is likely to increase further as we move towards wide-spread adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy generation. If the latent issues with battery quality continue to persist as is, there will be severe implications on both performance and safety of battery-powered systems. Our hope is that with our sound-based platform as an additional, physical mode for assessing battery quality, there is a large opportunity to dramatically improve how we select batteries for use in large, complex systems like electric vehicles and grid storage applications.

Beyond quality control, long term there is potential for sound-based analysis to get integrated into battery packs as in-use sensors that can better inform battery management systems during active operational control. With the ability to non-invasively and quickly gather information on the subtle physical changes that occur during operation, our ultrasound for batteries platform will help enable the efficient generation, storage, and use of energy worldwide


Last Modified: 02/01/2018
Modified by: Andrew G Hsieh
